--- title: GhApi keywords: fastai sidebar: home_sidebar summary: "A delightful and complete interface to GitHub's amazing API" description: "A delightful and complete interface to GitHub's amazing API" nb_path: "index.ipynb" ---
{% raw %}
{% endraw %}

GhApi provides 100% always-updated coverage of the entire GitHub API. Because we automatically convert the OpenAPI spec to a Pythonic API, GhApi is always up to date with the latest changes to GitHub APIs.

Using GhApi, you can do anything that you can do through the GitHub web interface or through the git client, such as:

  • Open, list, comment on, or modify issues or pull requests
  • Create, list, or modify git tags or GitHub releases, including uploading release assets
  • Configure and run GitHub Actions and webhooks
  • Set up GitHub users and organizations
  • Manage your deployments
  • ...and much, much more.

Install

Either pip install ghapi or conda install -c fastai ghapi.

How to use

First, create a GhApi object:

{% raw %} 
api = GhApi()
{% endraw %}

Every part of the API includes documentation directly in the api object itself. For instance, here's how to explore the groups of functionality provided by the API by displaying the object:

{% raw %} 
api
  • apps
  • oauth-authorizations
  • codes-of-conduct
  • emojis
  • enterprise-admin
  • billing
  • activity
  • gists
  • gitignore
  • issues
  • licenses
  • markdown
  • meta
  • orgs
  • actions
  • interactions
  • migrations
  • projects
  • repos
  • teams
  • reactions
  • rate-limit
  • checks
  • code-scanning
  • git
  • pulls
  • scim
  • search
  • users
{% endraw %}

Then we can explore the endpoints provided by the API in each group, e.g. for the git group:

{% raw %} 
api.git
  • create_blob
  • get_blob
  • create_commit
  • get_commit
  • list_matching_refs
  • get_ref
  • create_ref
  • update_ref
  • delete_ref
  • create_tag
  • get_tag
  • create_tree
  • get_tree
{% endraw %}

Here's how to learn about an endpoint you want to use, e.g.:

{% raw %} 
api.git.get_ref

git/get_ref(ref, repo, owner): Get a reference

{% endraw %}

In Jupyter Notebook full tab completion, parameter lists, etc are provided for all endpoints. Endpoints are called as standard Python methods:

{% raw %} 
api.git.get_ref(owner='fastai', repo='fastcore', ref='heads/master')
  • ref: refs/heads/master
  • node_id: MDM6UmVmMjI1NDYwNTk5OnJlZnMvaGVhZHMvbWFzdGVy
  • url: https://api.github.com/repos/fastai/fastcore/git/refs/heads/master
  • object:
    • sha: 0b188e9a4f200c5ad93c692bb10aa6e7ceb10d4c
    • type: commit
    • url: https://api.github.com/repos/fastai/fastcore/git/commits/0b188e9a4f200c5ad93c692bb10aa6e7ceb10d4c
{% endraw %}

For access to authenticated endpoints, pass a GitHub token. You can also pass any parameters you want auto-inserted into relevant methods, such as owner and repo:

{% raw %} 
api = GhApi(owner='fastai', repo='fastcore', token=github_token)
{% endraw %}

We can now repeat the previous method, but only need to pass ref:

{% raw %} 
api.git.get_ref('heads/master')
  • ref: refs/heads/master
  • node_id: MDM6UmVmMjI1NDYwNTk5OnJlZnMvaGVhZHMvbWFzdGVy
  • url: https://api.github.com/repos/fastai/fastcore/git/refs/heads/master
  • object:
    • sha: 0b188e9a4f200c5ad93c692bb10aa6e7ceb10d4c
    • type: commit
    • url: https://api.github.com/repos/fastai/fastcore/git/commits/0b188e9a4f200c5ad93c692bb10aa6e7ceb10d4c
{% endraw %}

Now that we've provided our token, we can use authenticated endpoints such as creating an issue:

issue = api.issues.create("Remember to check out GhApi!")

Since we've now checked out GhApi, let's close this issue. ðŸ˜Ž

api.issues.update(issue.number, state='closed')
